entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the complexities miners face when dealing with malleated transactions (txs) within the blockchain ecosystem. Miners are presented with a challenge when they encounter a malleated tx, as there's an understanding that a non-malleated version exists that would be more beneficial for them to process due to potentially higher fee rates. However, given the immediate availability of the malleated tx, miners might opt to include it in their mempool rather than seeking out the non-malleated counterpart, which they currently do not possess and may find cumbersome to unmalleate themselves. This decision is driven by the immediate economic incentive, as including the malleated tx could still prove profitable if it offers the best fee rate available at the time.
The conversation also touches upon the strategic considerations miners must weigh regarding such transactions. Accepting malleated txs without precaution could expose miners to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks, raising the necessity for policies that manage these risks effectively. One such policy could involve the implementation of a Replace-By-Fee (RBF) mechanism that requires sufficient increases in fee rates for transaction replacement, which may serve as a deterrent against potential abuses. Conversely, rejecting malleated txs outright could avoid these security concerns altogether but might result in lost revenue opportunities for miners. The dilemma underscores the absence of a one-size-fits-all approach and highlights the nuanced decision-making process miners undergo in optimizing their operations while safeguarding against vulnerabilities.
Furthermore, the dialogue underscores an appreciation for the identification and compilation of weight malleable opcodes, suggesting that the scope of this issue is more contained than initially presumed. A proposed resolution involves making MINIMAL_IF and minimal CScriptNum consensus enforced in future versions of Script, aiming to substantially mitigate weight malleability issues. Such technical enhancements would contribute to the robustness and efficiency of transaction processing on the blockchain, aligning with the broader goal of enhancing the system's integrity and reliability.
